author: __TriggerHappy__
body:
Some relevant points for interested potential investors:

- this is an OTC stock which means 1) there is no pre-market trading and 2) you cannot trade it on Robinhood. You will need to use another broker, like eTrade, Fidelity, etc. to purchase this stock. 

- this is going to open up tomorrow with a gigantic spike UNLESS news comes out in PM that somehow nullifies the expected reverse merger. Such news is unlikely at this point. 

- “buy the rumor, sell the news” is excellent advice for penny stocks, but does not really apply here. If you’ve followed this sub closely the last several weeks, you’ve undoubtedly seen PASO mentioned numerous times, but it’s never been a ‘pump’ stock so to speak, like IDEX, SOLO, GNUS, XSPA, IZEA, BIOC, BYFC, NBRV... the list goes on. This is largely due to its status as an OTC, but also because a gag order has been in place to outlaw any PR about the upcoming deal, therefore stifling any solid catalysts and subsequent short-term trader enthusiasm. This is not something penny stocks do; this is what huge companies (like the $50B company handling this merger) do. 

- so how tf does PASO play into this? Essentially, they’re a shell. CLX has been openly wanting to go public for some time now. The easiest way to go public without filing a separate IPO is an RM with a partnered, joint venture company who is already trading on the market. Hence the letter of intent (LOI) explicitly stating CLX’s intentions to merge with PASO. 

- I’m always a proponent of selling before news with pennies, simply because the rumor is almost ALWAYS more valuable than the news itself. Personally I believe this one to be different. You see on this sub, and others, tons of posts saying ‘this is a great long term hold’, and I hope most are right, but it’s highly unlikely. To me, this scenario looks like a similar type of deal as NKLA, going from ~$15 to $30, then $80s not much later. PTs I’m seeing are 0.3 (2.3x of 7/14 closing price), but that was before the news that TRU is involved. 

Open disclaimer: I own 9000 @ 0.114

As always, good luck to everyone, and may the stock winds be ever in your favor.

author: MasterCookSwag
body:
I realize that most people here are very new to investing and tend to think that's an accurate statement, so I'm sure there's going to be plenty of angry comments in my inbox after this, but that isn't remotely true. 

Commissions have been steadily declining since May day in 1975 with the removal of the price fixing requirements.  Reaching zero was a logical endpoint, they'd fallen from nearly $40-60 per trade in the 70s down to $20 in the 90s, $10 in the 00's, and sub $5 all well before Robinhood was a thing.  Charles Schwab(the person) had said his eventual goal was to get commissions down to 0 decades ago. 

And frankly Robinhood's model doesn't work.  It's not a profitable company.  There had been zero commission brokers before and they all failed as well because nobody figured out how to make it sustainable - from that standpoint Schwab and Fidelity have really lead the way in changing the brokerage platform to one that can sustain profits from things like fund management and NIM without the need to push commissions.  The entire reason why the TD deal happened is because they weren't ready for zero commissions and everyone else was.  RH can continue to burn VC cash for a while so it's of little consequence to them but let's not pretend like Schwab, Vanguard, and Fidelity have been shifting their revenue streams for decades towards management fees and NIM because of a broker that just started.  
  
Also, to be quite frank, Robinhood largely caters to a trader that isn't profitable for most brokers.  They hold low amounts of cash but trade often and don't care about spreads much - this is how they're able to generate significantly more cashflow from order flow than other firms.  

Crediting robinhood with creating the current commission environment basically ignores everything that's happened in securities regulation and brokerage structure from the 70s till today and instead just presumes that there wasn't already downward trajectory in fees prior to like 2016.  I get that people who just started investing in the last few years, likely with Robinhood, might not be aware of all of these things so there's that, but IMO it's somewhat absurd to credit them here.  It's like saying they were the reason your team won the game when they showed up to the stadium with 2 minutes left, and made a field goal while your team was already up by four touchdowns.  The only way you could think that is if you only turned the game on with a minute and a half left.

author: shotcatch
body: Sure Dutch, what I would do if I were your age is determine your risk tolerance for your split between stocks and bonds but at your age you probably want to be 100% stocks. The next thing is to use low-cost index funds like through Vanguard Schwab or Fidelity.  Etfs  like VTI, SCHB,for domestic and VXUS, SCHF for international.  Studies say you do better when you go all-in rather than timing the market but I'm too risk-averse, I've always been.  What I would probably do is gradually dollar cost average into the market over a period of time. Kind of like you do what with your company 401K when you are contributing a little bit each paycheck.  For instance if you had $20 to 30,000 I would want to average in over 12 months you would put 1/12 each month into the market. Personally I feel the market is  being manipulated by fed policy and there's  "irrational exuberance" in the market so I believe the market will correct in 3-12 mo's. Read up about the three or four fund / ETF portfolio. It keeps it simple. if you want to be more speculative I would use 5% of your investments to buy individual stocks, gold, silver,  etc but not expose the majority of your holdings. Bogleheads.com is a good site where most of the participants believe in indexing, low-cost, and not timing the market. I think Warren Buffett said that investing should be about as boring as watching grass grow.I'm telling you what I would tell my own children. Good luck. You have time on your side. Try not to let worry, fear, greed, pride , ego control your investment decisions. If it sounds too good to be true it probably is. Hope this helps Dutch.

author: Tiaan
body:
I moved out of vanguard a while ago because of their outdated UI and no 2FA option that wasn't SMS based. I can't imagine how a huge financial firm still offers SMS based 2fA without realizing how huge of a security flaw it is with sim swapping. At least fidelity and Schwab offer an authenticator-like app with symantec VIP. Vanguard has been behind on the times for a while now and shows no signs of getting with it.

With all of the great brokerage account options out there, there's very little reason to use Vanguard. Don't get me wrong, I love the Vanguard funds, but you can access all of their ETFs in many other platforms. For example, you can literally buy fractional shares of Vanguard ETFs in Fidelity for no extra cost at the same expense ratio as you get in Vanguard. That's something that you can't even do in Vanguard itself!

author: BobBetsOnWallStreet
body: I’m using fidelity. My research process for pennies. Look here, stocktwits, yahoo boards, Schwab, and fidelity for undervalued stocks that have catalysts. After I find something I will research it. I look at financials (is the company close to bankruptcy or making a profit?), look at insiders buying or selling, look at sec filings, study the graph to see its history. I legit would not hold most pennies long term unless my research pans out and they look undervalued. Most pennies run on hype and will crash hard after the sell off. Also for biotechs I always check there pipeline to see what drugs are in the works. Is it in phase 1, 2, or 3? Is it something that is innovative and showing good results? Are they filing a NDA soon or is a PDUFA coming up?

author: InvestingNerd2020
body:
A few things:

1) Get a maintenance free checking account. Capital One is a good choice.

2) Get a high yield savings account. Go with Capital One. Put your emergency funds there. Usually 3-6 months of your routine expenses.

3) Open a Roth IRA with Fidelity if your income is below $124k per year.  The max contribution is $6k per year or $500 per month. Invest in FZROX. In your 30s add the lowest costing bond Index mutual fund (FXNAX).

4) If you have any extra funds after steps 1-3, then invest in technology ETFs (FTEC, VGT, QQQ) and any total USA stock market fund (ITOT).

author: BlissfulThinkr
body:
Honest answer: if 3k is a lot, opt for broad ETFs with low expense ratios from the big guys. From what I’ve heard from Schwab themselves, the robo-advisors make a real difference against tax loss harvesting and essentially building your own personal ETF. That’s why the advertised robo products require like 100k or more. You have to have cash so the algorithm can re-balance and/or rotate when necessary.

Given the comparison expense ratios, Id stick with Vanguard, Schwab, Fidelity, BlackRock ETFs. For example, Vanguard’s funds are straightforward to comprehend and their website explains performance and holdings quite well. Just as a comparison: Vanguard’s VOO (s&p500), VTI (all USA), VT (all world), VUG or MGK (growth), VIG (dividend), and sector-specific products are all solid for 3k total. Could split your money across multiple funds. Likewise, QQQ (growth) is one of the best performing ETFs out there and only has an expense ratio of .20%.

There is an entire investment strategy devoted to this. It is called ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance). 

Ishares, Fidelity, Goldman Sachs, and other large firms have ESG oriented funds. Anything from. author: Zidualz
body:
Found an article by Syntegon, dated June 8, that adds some color on the potential market size for glass vials and many useful tidbits on Corning’s Valor glass. 

GLW previously stated the firm “expect[s] ultimate annual sales to match our cumulative investment level, which could be as much as $4 billion” w.r.t. Valor glass. Same Corning update suggested that this sales levels would materialize upon the product’s “successful adoption” by the market. Reasonably likely that demand from clinical trials and production of Covid vaccine/treatments alone would be sufficient to satisfy the threshold for “successful adoption” if not more; not surprising per se, covid is merely a catalyst. If true, then the marginal contribution of Valor sales to the bottom line will be substantial.

Links to referenced sources:

 [Pharmaceutical Glass Packaging 2017](https://s22.q4cdn.com/662497847/files/doc_news/disclosure/valor_FAQ.pdf)

[Examining Supply Chain Risk For Pandemic Preparedness](https://pharmablog.syntegon.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/8/2020/06/whitepaper-Corning-Valor.pdf)

author: herrblumenkohl
body:
By [pharma tech](https://www.corning.com/worldwide/en/products/pharmaceutical-technologies/valor-glass.html) I only mean their glass vials segment. Another segment of their business that will benefit from pandemic are [life sciences](https://www.corning.com/worldwide/en/products/life-sciences.html) which is basically lab-glassware.

US gov is already placing orders for glass vials even overseas. What is interesting, some companies are testing vaccines that will require [two rounds of doses](https://twitter.com/megtirrell/status/1285601948809535489?s=20). 

Given the fact, that we are slowly going into recession, the demand for e.g. new smartphones/TVs will decline, so will the revenues from Corning's Display and Gorilla Glass segments. 

There was an [interesting article](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/07/13/coronavirus-vaccine-corning-glass/) about whole vaccine vials and syringes supply chain in Washington Post and it's quite updated.

author: JoJoMaMa85
body:
Really depends. Some days, I'll take a chance. On days like today, I sat back and didn't play. I used to sit and watch the market all day in the beginning, but I've learned that doing that isn't going to change much. If my order isn't filled right away, I'll rethink if the play is worth it. Bid/Ask spread is a big factor for me on whether I'll play. 

It's earning season right now, so I may play more. I have been burnt before when playing earnings. I'll typically do the run up to earnings and then sell right before. On Monday, I sold a couple of $GLW calls right before their earnings this morning. I had almost a 100% return on those.

author: TheTigersAreNotReal
body:
GLW: Glass manufacturer that is used in vials, phones, TVs, and other medical/commercial appliances. They have a contract to produce vials for Pfizer, and received a grant from the government to ensure that they will be able to produce enough vials for the future vaccine. Had their price target upgraded to $33 by Citigroup, currently oversold at $25.75

Don’t know when this thing is gonna moon again, but I hope it’s soon. Probably needs to announce another biomed contract to turn more heads. White knuckling these calls hoping the market realizes its value soon

author: math1024
body:
The main difference between 5G and the previous roll outs is just a lot more fiber and small cell antennas. I think the best 5G plays would be fiber companies like GLW, COMM, and OCC.

There's also been [legislation](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Executive_Order_13858) promoting onshoring so you might want to focus on american manufacturers.

author: ValenTom
body:
Initiated a position in Prudential Financial in my Roth IRA today. I was previously targeting Realty Income but the share price is just a tad higher than where I’d like to continue accumulating. As long as PRU stays around these levels I’ll continue accumulating 8-10 shares per month for the foreseeable future. 

Brings my Roth IRA to five total holdings as I develop a DGI portfolio there.

CVS

Corning Glass

Prudential Financial
